Boss.name: Defense Nucleus
Boss.desc: Killing elite monsters spawns an Alpha Construct with bonus 300% damage and 300% health . Limited to 4 (+4 per stack) .
Boss.notes:
The Defense Nucleus is a boss item in Risk of Rain 2, dropped by the   Xi Construct, added in the Survivors of the Void expansion.
Whenever the holder defeats an Elite monster, one friendly   Alpha Construct is spawned at that location, with greatly increased stats. Up to 4 (+4 per stack) can be spawned.


== Notes ==
The Alpha Constructs will disappear if you are further than a 100 meters away for 30s. This is quite beneficial when staying in one area for a long time such as a Holdout zone event.
Due to the global ally limit, high stacks of this item may prevent other allies from spawning, e.g.,  Empathy Cores and  Void Allies.
The  Artifact of Honor makes this item very useful, as the player can accumulate an army of Alpha Constructs over the course of a stage.
The  Forgive Me Please will never trigger the item's effect, even if the Artifact of Honor is enabled.
Alpha Constructs spawned by the Defense Nucleus can become   Voidtouched by a   Void Infestor, and will no longer help the Survivors. These are particularly dangerous since these allied Alpha Constructs are much stronger than a normal one.
Unlike most other ally-summoning items, the Defense Nucleus is given to   Engineer's turrets. Each turret tracks its own allied Alpha Construct limit separately, so a turret can spawn up to 4 extra Alpha Constructs per stack of Defense Nucleus. Turrets must be the ones to land the killing blow on Elites to spawn their own Alpha Constructs, however. If the turrets and Engineer can kill enough elites, they can have a total of 12 Alpha Construct allies with just a single Defense Nucleus.
The  Lysate Cell gives Engineer an extra turret, increasing the max potential to 16 Alpha Constructs.
If a turret is a replaced, its deployable count reference will be lost while its spawned Alpha Constructs will not be affected. The new turret will then be able to spawn more Alpha Constructs.


== Lore ==
"Excellent!  How did you find it?"

"We took down one of those floating fortune tellers--"

"Xi Construct."

"Sure.  Anyway, we took it down and recovered the sample."

"May I see it?"

"This is it."

"This?  What happened?  I thought you said it was glowing."

"That's right.  It was.  Before I scrapped it."

"...You ...what?"

"I scrapped it."

"You were finally able to recover a sample from the Xi Construct, and you scrapped it?  Do you realize monumental importance of the samples we've been gathering?"

"I realize the monumental danger.  I've read the lab files.  Daimera's crippled in one hand.  Veirs was THIS close to electrocuting herself.  After Fitz nearly KILLED his ENTIRE team for a VASE, you think I'm going to haul a mysterious glowing orb back here?  HELL.  NO."

"...Well, what's done is done.  I guess I'll analyze what's left.  Anything else?"

"Yeah, I was thinking we could call it a 'Defense Nucleus'."

"..."

"In the file."

"No."

Boss.name: Empathy Cores
Boss.desc: Every 30 seconds, summon two Solus Probes that gain +100% (+100% per stack) damage per ally on your team .
Boss.notes:
The Empathy Cores are a boss item in Risk of Rain 2, dropped by the   Solus Control Unit.  
They summon two friendly   Solus Probes, one colored red and one colored green, who will attack enemies near the player with a laser beam. Similarly to  Queen's Gland, these minions have stronger stats than their regular counterparts, with 4 times the health and a damage stat that increases by 100% (+100% per stack) per ally on the team, including each other but not their owner, starting their damage at 2x if all of them are alive. The Solus Probes are re-summoned every 30 seconds if they are destroyed and they only take 25% of damage dealt by AoE attacks due to a hidden +300 armor bonus against them. 


== Notes ==
Allies include drones and turrets, other players, and minions spawned by items like  Queen's Gland, as well as ghosts spawned by  Happiest Mask. Essentially, every entity that appears on the column on the left side of the HUD.
If the Artifact of Swarms is active, four Probes will spawn instead of two, augmenting their damage output.
The Empathy Cores is one of the few blacklisted items that   Engineer's turrets will not inherit.
When the   final boss steals the player's items, he will gain his own Probes and they will attack the player, dealing high damage.
This becomes even more dangerous if he steals multiple Empathy Cores or Queen's Glands, as the Probes will become extremely powerful.
  Loader's   Spiked Fist can pull the Probes to her, although this will not damage them.
The Probes have collision, allowing players to stand on them. However, it may be difficult to remain there given how they move around when enemies are near.
The Probes will not respawn once the player has hit the ally limit of 16, making 14 allies the maximum amount that can be active at a time to ensure that the Probes can always be active. Acquiring yet another ally once the limit is reached (such as summoning a friendly   Aurelionite with a  Halcyon Seed) will not cause the Probes to despawn; however, if one of them dies then it will not respawn until the player has 15 or fewer allies again.
 Spare Drone Parts: Despite the probes not visually obtaining any augmentations, they will gain all of the buffs and chaingun granted by this item, and since   Col. Droneman is another ally, the damage it deals will get boosted as well.

Boss.name: Faulty Conductor
Boss.desc: Every 15 (-20% per stack) seconds , release a wave of electricity that energizes nearby allies for 7 seconds. Energized allies gain +30% attack and movement speed , and ALWAYS land critical strikes with electric items and attacks.
Boss.notes:
The Faulty Conductor is a boss item in Risk of Rain 2, added in the  Alloyed Collective expansion and dropped by the   Alloy Hunter.
Every 15 (-20% per stack) seconds, the user releases a wave of electricity that energizes nearby allies for 7 seconds. Energized allies gain +30% attack and movement speed, and ALWAYS land critical strikes with electric items and attacks.


== Activating ==
Damage from the following items is electrical:

 Ukulele
 Luminous Shot
 Faraday Spur
 Kinetic Dampener
 Unstable Tesla Coil
 N'kuhana's Opinion
 Electric Boomerang
 Genesis Loop
 Little Disciple
 Charged Perforator
 Polylute
 Sautéed Worms
 Preon Accumulator
 Royal Capacitor
 Silence Between Two Strikes
 Wake of Vultures (by extension)
 N'kuhana's Retort (Projectile only)
Damage from the following skills is electrical:

  Artificer's   Plasma Bolt,   Charged Nano-Bomb, and   Ion Surge.
  Loader's   M551 Pylon and   Thunder Gauntlet (AoE only).
  Captain's   Power Tazer and   Beacon: Shocking (when first launched).
  False Son's   Meridian's Will and   Lunar Stakes (AoE only).
Damage from the following drones is electrical:

  Bombardment Drone
    ADMIN-OVERRIDE
Multiple enemy attacks are also tagged as electrical.

  Wandering Vagrant
  Jellyfish
  Overloading Worm (projectiles)


== Tips ==
This particular boss item is extremely rare. While any other boss item can drop naturally from fighting the associated Teleporter Boss at any point during a run, Faulty Conductor only appears during the   Conduit Canyon stage's Teleporter Boss, which can only be fought once per run.
A  Trophy Hunter's Tricorn,  Recycler, Overgrown 3D Printer, or the Artifact of Prestige can help make it easier to find this item for the logbook entry.
5 Faulty Conductors are needed for the time between pulses to be shorter than the duration of the buff, allowing the buff to be active permanently.
Additional stacks are not helpful to the player that has them, since the only benefit of stacking is decreased time between pulses.

Boss.name: Functional Coupler
Boss.desc: Hold 1 additional equipment (+1 per stack) . Press the interact and equipment buttons to cycle through held equipment.
Boss.notes:
The Functional Coupler is a boss item in Risk of Rain 2, added in the  Alloyed Collective expansion and dropped by the   Solus Amalgamator.
It grants the user the ability to hold 1 (+1 per stack) additional equipment. The user can cycle through held equipment by pressing the interact and use equipment keys at the same time.


== Notes ==
This item functions somewhat similarly to   MUL-T's   Retool, which allows MUL-T to hold up to two different equipments.
However, stacking this item allows the user to have an indefinite amount of equipment.
The item allows you to hold multiple aspects. For example, you can equip both  Ifrit's Distinction and  Silence Between Two Strikes, and swap between them to change your aspect on the fly.
If the player loses the item, all held equipment except the one in active use drops where they stand.
Any dropped equipment will have their cooldowns reset.
If the player has a  Seed of Life in the extra equipment slot and not the main equipment slot, it will not revive the player if they die.


== Tips ==
Consider pairing an  Executive Card with a  Recycler to maximize item macro and get as many items as possible from Multishop Terminals, and re-rolling undesired items.
This item allows for more build diversity in runs; For example, you could stack  Bundle of Fireworks together with a  Remote Caffeinator for a firework build, while also stacking on-kill items with a  Forgive Me Please for a Forgive Me Please build.
Since Firework builds work better with  Pocket I.C.B.M., this also opens the door for simultaneously equipping the  Disposable Missile Launcher. Prior to the Functional Coupler being added, this was only possible using   MUL-T's Retool.

Boss.name: Genesis Loop
Boss.desc: Falling below 25% health causes you to explode, dealing 6000% base damage . Recharges every 30 / (2 +1 per stack ) seconds .
Boss.notes:
The Genesis Loop is a boss item introduced in the Hidden Realms Update, dropped by the   Wandering Vagrant.
If the holder falls to 25% of their max health or less, they create a 100m explosion that inflicts 6000% damage on any enemies in the vicinity, similar to the Vagrants' signature supernova attack. This explosion has a short charging period, which decreases with increased attack speed.
The player can only explode once every 15 seconds, though this cooldown period is reduced by having more Genesis Loops. If the player happens to still be below 25% health when this cooldown is finished, they will immediately prepare to explode again, even if they have not taken damage recently.
The explosion has a proc coefficient of 1.0.


== Notes ==
Correction: The in-game description of 30s (-50% per stack) is incorrect.
The Survivor's model will visibly crackle with electricity when the Genesis Loop is fully charged.
The 25% HP threshold is calculated using maximum HP plus maximum shield. For instance, if the player has 750 max HP and 250 max shield, the Genesis Loop will trigger when they reach 250 HP.


== Tips ==
While the explosion is charging, the player should try to find the best place to explode and damage the most possible enemies.
The  Old War Stealthkit makes this easier, since both items are triggered by taking extensive damage and the Stealthkit grants increased movement speed.
  Engineer makes excellent use of this item, as his turrets are expendable enough to reliably trigger the explosion without putting Engineer himself in peril.
  REX's self-damaging abilities make activating the Genesis Loop much easier, and since they can rapidly recover health they can recover from peril safely.
By paying the second or third offering at a Shrine of Blood, the player can take a fixed amount of damage and explode on demand, without needing to risk taking damage from enemies.
By obtaining 38 stacks of  Personal Shield Generator, and making sure their shield never regenerates, the player can stay permanently below the detonation threshold, though this many stacks of Personal Shield Generator may be difficult to obtain in a normal run.
The  Power Elixir triggers simultaneously with the Genesis Loop and does not prevent the explosion from going off, healing the player immediately once they reach the threshold to activate the Genesis Loop. This makes it considerably safer to activate, although this is limited by how many Power Elixirs the player has.


== Math ==
The cooldown is determined by the formula 30 / (amount + 1)

The full time between blasts is determined by the formula 30 / (amount + 1) + 3 / attackSpeed + 2

30 / (amount + 1) is the recharge time, after detonation.
3 / attackSpeed is the charge time, after the Genesis Loop activates but before detonation.
2 is the detonation duration.


== Lore ==

> Both sides of loop have organelles at end; one has positive charge, one has negative charge

Boss.name: Halcyon Seed
Boss.desc: Summon Aurelionite during the teleporter event. It has 100% (+50% per stack) damage and 100% (+100% per stack) health .
Boss.notes:
The Halcyon Seed is a boss item introduced in the Scorched Acres Update, dropped by defeating   Aurelionite at Gilded Coast.
Upon beginning a Teleporter Event, the player will lose all of their Halcyon Seeds and Aurelionite will spawn as an ally. She will fight for the player until the Teleporter is charged, at which point she will instantly die. The player will retrieve their Halcyon Seed when Aurelionite dies (regardless of whether she died at the end of the Teleporter Event or was killed in some other way). In multiplayer, players who die after Aurelionite is summoned will still recover their Halcyon Seeds when Aurelionite dies.
This item stacks based on the total amount held by all players combined (items held by   Engineer's   turrets do not count), similarly to the Lepton Daisy. Each Halcyon Seed beyond the first gives Aurelionite an additional 100% health and some extra damage.
If the player is fighting   Mithrix and is in phase 4, Aurelionite will spawn and help the player.
If the player is fighting the   False Son and is in phase 3, Aurelionite will spawn and fight against the player while keeping the increased stats from any excess stacks of Halcyon Seed. Defeating False Son in this way clears the Purified Freedom challenge and unlocks the   False Son as a playable survivor.


== Notes ==
Correction: While Aurelionite's Health increases by 100% per stack of Halcyon Seed, Aurelionite's Damage is actually equal to the square root of the number of stacks of Halcyon Seed rounded to the nearest 10%

The Halcyon Seed is one of the few blacklisted items that   Engineer's turrets will not inherit.
If theArtifact of Command is active when Aurelionite is defeated at Gilded Coast, a Yellow Command Essence will drop, but it will only allow this item to be selected.
If the Artifact of Swarms is active, two Aurelionites with half the normal health will spawn at Gilded Coast. However, only one Aurelionite will spawn during Teleporter Events.
If the player damages an allied Aurelionite via items such as  Helfire Tincture, she may attempt to attack them. However, she will not do any damage.
The   final boss has special dialogue if any Halcyon Seeds are brought to the fight. Upon seeing Aurelionite, he exclaims "THE GUARDIAN...? IMPOSSIBLE...!" or "THE WRETCHED GUARDIAN!" If he manages to defeat Aurelionite, he states either "YOU CANNOT DEFY ME, GUARDIAN," or "RETURN TO DIRT, GUARDIAN."
The   final boss also has a unique dialogue if the   Heretic has the Halcyon Seed: "THE HERETIC… THE GUARDIAN… HOW? WHO PULLS YOUR STRINGS, VERMIN?"
When Aurelionite dies while allied with the player, she has a chance of dropping Aurelionite's Log.
Aurelionite can become   Voidtouched by a   Void Infestor, which causes her to attack players. This can become a serious problem during Teleporter Events if any Void Infestors are near.
Be wary of attacking   Void Reavers that may be near Aurelionite, as she will make no attempt to avoid their death implosion and will be instantly killed.


== Lore ==
Brother, what is this...? Why is it misshapen and weak? Was there an error in my design?

Guardian. Come to me. Allow me to see your construction.

...

So I see.

These are not the correct ratios.

This is no minor error, Brother. You have purposefully deviated from the design. For what purpose have you done this? You cannot weave a construct from such an abundance of soul. You know it is too unstable - that it is too unpredictable and too frail. I have told you this, and yet you have wasted the materials I have gathered - and exhausted your own strength to fabricate this miscreation.

To what benefit?

At its best, it can be no more than an inferior servant; it is deficient in the compounds that were to give it fortitude and strength. At its worst, it will betray us.

You have created the first being of this world which threatens us. We cannot keep it here. Attempting to destroy it will risk its retaliation... I will prepare one of the vaults for it to be sealed away, while it is still young and naive.

What a foolish mistake you have made, brother.

I expect you to return the design to me. I cannot allow you to build another construct with so much power - and with such little control. I will build the rest of our guardians; by my hand, they will be weak, but at least they will be loyal.

Go home. I will deal with this creature. We can discuss a better project for you when I return.

Boss.name: Irradiant Pearl
Boss.desc: Increases ALL stats by 10% (+10% per stack) .
Boss.notes:
The Irradiant Pearl is a yellow item introduced in the Hidden Realms Update.
It can only be obtained from a Cleansing Pool in exchange for a lunar item, and increases all the holder's stats by 10% (+10% per stack).
The Irradiant Pearl has a drop rate of 20%. Its common counterpart is the  Pearl, which only increases the holder's health.
When combined with both the scarcity of Cleansing Pools and the general unlikelihood of players having mass amounts of lunar items to trade, the Irradiant Pearl becomes one of the rarest items, if not the rarest item, in the game.  


== Notes ==
The  Recycler cannot be used to transform other boss items into an Irradiant Pearl, or vice versa.
Though a Shrine of Order can be used to fulfill the same purpose.
Irradiant Pearls cannot be obtained while the Artifact of Command is active. Cleansing Pools do not spawn, and neither the Pearl or the Irradiant Pearl can be selected from Yellow Command Essences.
While Irradiant Pearls can be scrapped with a Scrapper for  Yellow Item Scraps and are the same rarity as other boss items, Yellow Scrap cannot be used with the Cleansing Pool, and Irradiant Pearls will never be offered by an Overgrown 3D Printer.
Increasing maximum health or regeneration is not considered healing, so picking up an Irradiant Pearl does not fail the Naturopath challenge.
The Irradiant Pearl only multiplies base armor, meaning it provides a maximum benefit of 2 armor on Survivors like   Loader, and gives no armor to Survivors without base armor.
Correction: The in-game description of adding 10% regeneration is incorrect; it actually increases regeneration by a flat 0.1 (+ 0.02 per level) HP/s per stack. This is effectively a 10% increase for most Survivors, except for   Loader,   Acrid, and the   Heretic.


== Lore ==
Oh, that is… strange. That is unlike the other pearls.

Do not be mistaken – his influence is still dark. Despite how beautiful your pearl is… it is not from a place of kindness. It cannot be.

Boss.name: Item Scrap, Yellow
Boss.desc: Does nothing. Prioritized when used with 3D Printers .
Boss.notes:
Item Scrap is a group of items in Risk of Rain 2 with no passive effects. However, when using a 3D Printer or Cauldron, any Item Scrap of the required rarity will be prioritized and consumed before any other item. 
These items cannot be found normally. Instead, using a Scrapper to get rid of an item or a Drone Scrapper to get rid of a Drone will produce an Item Scrap of the same rarity:

White (Common) items and drones produce  Item Scrap, White
Green (Uncommon) items and drones produce  Item Scrap, Green
Red (Legendary) items and drones produce  Item Scrap, Red
Yellow (Boss) items produce  Item Scrap, Yellow


== Notes ==
The  Recycler cannot be used on these items, and they do not appear in Scrappers.
If the player uses a Shrine of Order while holding Item Scrap, it is possible for all their items of the same rarity as that Item Scrap to be transformed into Item Scrap.
If upgraded using  Benthic Bloom, it may transform into any item of the target rarity, unrestricted by category.
Despite working similarly to 3D Printers, no Item Scrap equivalent exists for use in Cleansing Pools.
If Artifact of Devotion is enabled, when a Lemurian follower is killed, it will drop one Scrap in the same tier as the item that was offered to hatch it.
Item Scraps  White,  Green, and  Red can be obtained through the Drone Scrapper.
Item Scraps can be duplicated via Crafting.


== Lore ==
All scrap have the same lore entry.

“While officially licensed materials are always recommended, hobbyists are known to take matters into their own hands when in a pinch. Don’t have any materials up to par? Make your own! Recycling old parts can be a fun way to create materials for your projects.”

- The Ultimate Hobby Guide: Kitbashing and 3D Printing

Boss.name: Little Disciple
Boss.desc: Fire a tracking wisp for 300% (+300% per stack) damage . Fires every 1.6 seconds while sprinting. Fire rate increases with movement speed .
Boss.notes:
The Little Disciple is a boss item introduced in the Scorched Acres Update, dropped by the   Grovetender. 
While the holder is sprinting, they periodically shoot homing wisps at enemies, dealing 300% (+300% per stack) damage per wisp. The speed at which the wisps are fired increases as movement speed increases.
The wisps have a range of 40m and a proc coefficient of 1.0.


== Math ==
The time in seconds between each fired wisp is determined by the formula 35 / (3 ⋅ movementSpeed)


== Tips ==
This item is most useful on Survivors that have the Agile keyword on their skills, such as   Huntress, allowing them to sprint constantly while using their skills and gain many bonus attacks from the Little Disciple.
Despite their movement,   Engineer's   TR58 Carbonizer Turrets do not benefit from this item, as they are not sprinting.

Boss.name: Mired Urn
Boss.desc: While in combat, the nearest 1 (+1 per stack) enemies to you within 13m will be 'tethered' to you, dealing 100% damage per second, applying tar , and healing you for 100% of the damage dealt.
Boss.notes:
The Mired Urn is a boss item in Risk of Rain 2, dropped by the   Clay Dunestrider. 
Whenever enemies are within 13m of the holder, a tendril of tar will reach out from them to an enemy. This tendril inflicts the {  Tar debuff, reducing the enemy's movement speed, while continuously damaging it for 25% damage every 0.25 seconds with a proc coefficient of 0.0 while healing the holder for the damage dealt. 
The maximum number of tendrils that can be active at once is equal to the number of held Mired Urns.


== Notes ==
It is not necessary to hit an enemy to activate this effect, but the player must be in combat. Read the notes for  Red Whip to see which skills preserve the out-of-combat property.
The Mired Urn's {  Tar debuff counts toward the  Death Mark.
Even though The Urn has a proc coefficient of 0.0, it can critically strike. However, the aforementioned property prevents it from activating on-crit items such as  Predatory Instincts.
If the damage is blocked by  Tougher Times,  Safer Spaces, or because the target is {  Immune, the holder will not receive any healing.


== Tips ==
Melee Survivors who stay close to the action will make the most effective use of the Mired Urn, such as   Loader,   Mercenary, and   Acrid.
  Engineer also excels with this item, allowing his turrets to constantly drain health from enemies, increasing both their damage and survivability.
Pair the Mired Urn with the  Focus Crystal to increase the damage dealt and health restored.

Notes:

Boss.name: Pearl
Boss.desc: Increases maximum health by 10% (+10% per stack) .
Boss.notes:
The Pearl is a yellow item introduced in the Hidden Realms Update.
It can only be obtained from a Cleansing Pool in exchange for a lunar item, and increases the holder's maximum health by 10% (+10% per stack).
The Pearl has a drop chance of 80%. Its rare counterpart is the  Irradiant Pearl, which increases all other stats in addition to maximum health.


== Notes ==
The  Recycler cannot be used to transform other boss items into a Pearl, or vice versa.
Though a Shrine of Order can be used to fulfill the same purpose.
Pearls cannot be obtained while the Artifact of Command is active. Cleansing Pools do not spawn, and neither the Pearl or the Irradiant Pearl can be selected from Yellow Command Essences.
While Pearls can be scrapped with a Scrapper for  Yellow Item Scraps and are the same rarity as other boss items, Yellow Scrap cannot be used with the Cleansing Pool, and Pearls will never be offered by an Overgrown 3D Printer.
Increasing maximum health is not considered healing, so picking up a Pearl does not fail the Naturopath challenge.

Boss.name: Planula
Boss.desc: Heal from incoming damage for 15 (+15 per stack) .
Boss.notes:
The Planula is a boss item in Risk of Rain 2, dropped by the   Grandparent.
Whenever the holder takes damage, they immediately heal 15 HP (+15 HP per stack), making it extremely useful against monsters that attack with rapid, low-damage hits.


== Notes ==
Damage-over-time debuffs, fall damage and self-inflicted damage trigger the heal.
Damage taken from Void Fog, however, does not.
Planula's healing is applied if the incoming hit does not ignore armor and before taking damage. As such it may prevent the holder from dying. However, this also means that the player will also not be at full health after the hit. (See Receiving Damage for more details for the order of events).


== Tips ==
The Planula works well with the  Helfire Tincture to recoup HP lost while burning.
  REX makes excellent use of the Planula, since it heals them when they pay HP for abilities.
This item can pair well with the  Repulsion Armor Plate to further mitigate damage, although both these items fall off in effectiveness as the difficulty increases.
Both of these item can prove to be a hindrance when fighting   Mithrix's final phase where the player's power is reset before reclaiming their items back. However, this mostly applies to weak, fast-hitting attacks, such as   Double Tap and   Auto-Nailgun.
This item can drastically reduce the self damage   Sojourn does, and paired with a  Repulsion Armor Plate can effectively cancel it out, making it ideal for use on   Seeker.


== Lore ==
"Yes – the egg. The grandparent incubates the eggs."

"And the child?"

"The child lays the egg."

"And the egg becomes the…?"

"The parent."

"Okay. And the parent does what?"

"Takes care of children – and the grandparent."

"And the grandparent is the youngest?"

"Younger than the child, yes. But not the youngest."

"Who is the youngest?"

"The parent."

"…"

Boss.name: Queen's Gland
Boss.desc: Every 30 seconds, summon a Beetle Guard with bonus 300% damage and 100% health . Can have up to 1 (+1 per stack) Guards at a time.
Boss.notes:
The Queen's Gland is a boss item in Risk of Rain 2, dropped by the   Beetle Queen.
The holder gains a   Beetle Guard ally that fights for them. This Beetle Guard is much more powerful than normal; it deals 4 times as much damage and has twice as much health as a regular Beetle Guard. The number of Beetle Guards a player can have at once is equal to the number of Queen's Glands they have.
A new Beetle Guard is summoned as soon as the game finds a suitable location and if the player does not have the maximum number of Guards yet.

The respawn timer of 30 seconds is bugged and does not work properly. It starts with a timer of 0, so upon item pick up the Beetle Guard will attempt to spawn immediately. There is also a second internal cooldown timer of 1 second, which is used to retry a spawn when it has failed, e.g. because of chosen location. However, this internal cooldown is used even when a spawn has succeeded.
If the player damages the allied Beetle Guard with an item such as the  Helfire Tincture, it will give chase and attempt to attack the player. However, it will not do any damage.
If the Artifact of Swarms is active, one Queen's Gland will result in two Beetle Guards spawning with half health.
The Queen's Gland is one of the few blacklisted items that   Engineer's turrets will not inherit.

Lunar.name: Beads of Fealty
Lunar.desc: Seems to do nothing... but...
Lunar.notes:
The Beads of Fealty are a lunar item introduced in the Hidden Realms Update. It is unlocked after completing the True Respite challenge by obliterating yourself at the Obelisk at   A Moment, Fractured.
Upon pickup, they offer no benefits or detriments to the player beyond giving them an extra item. However, when the player enters the Celestial Portal to enter A Moment, Fractured and obliterates themself at the Obelisk, they will be transported to A Moment, Whole before ending the run. This secret area contains one of the four   Twisted Scavengers, each of which have their own preset list of items and equipment unlike regular   Scavengers.
Stacking the Beads beyond the first pickup has no additional effect.


== Notes ==
Since most Lunar items have an effect that is severely detrimental to the player, the Beads of Fealty provide players with an item to convert with a Cleansing Pool without risk.
Dying to the   Twisted Scavenger after obliterating will not grant mastery skins.
Beads of Fealty cannot be obtained in either the Eclipse or Simulacrum game modes, as A Moment, Fractured is inaccessible in both.


== Lore ==
The master of this world is a benevolent protector. Our savior. Despite the natures of its various inhabitants, he has made a peaceful place here. 

Peace comes at a cost, of course. Some things are strictly forbidden. Above all, there is one item that cannot be tolerated – to possess it is to surely perish: a strange, heavy, and deeply entrancing set of beads that seem to speak with whoever holds them. 

To discover them among one’s community is to create a dark, rippling panic. It is not long after they are found that Providence, the mighty protector, appears in a thunderous instant to pursue their owner and solemnly take a life he swore to defend.

It is no physical property of the beads themselves which provoke such a drastic response - but instead, what they represent. They are a symbol, and to carry them is a dark promise to undo the world – to cast to oblivion all people who find their final place here, all in exchange for a doomed return to ruinous way. The elusive, sinister intelligence with whom these beads represent a pact seems known only to the bearer - and to Providence himself.

One thing, however, is known to anyone who has borne witness to these beads: a cruel, cackling laughter that erupts as blood and coins of favor are spilled, abruptly silenced as the beads are destroyed. Where they come from isn’t known, but should you encounter these beads you must leave them far, far behind. 

Never look back.

Lunar.name: Brittle Crown
Lunar.desc: 30% chance on hit to gain 2 (+2 per stack) gold . Scales over time. Lose gold on taking damage equal to 100% (+100% per stack) of the maximum health percentage you lost .
Lunar.notes:
The Brittle Crown is a lunar item in Risk of Rain 2. 
The player has a 30% chance to gain gold equal to 8%(+8% per stack) of the Small Chest any time they hit an enemy, but they will surrender a percentage of their gold to any enemy that deals damage to them. The proportion of gold surrendered is equal to the proportion of maximum health lost (+100% per stack). Self-inflicted damage, such as from the  Helfire Tincture, will subtract the holder's gold accordingly but return it shortly after.
The chance to gain gold when damaging enemies is affected by the proc coefficient. The amount of gold gained is also affected by the difficulty coefficient.


== Tips ==
  Engineer's turrets are affected by the Brittle Crown, but they gain and lose gold independently from the player. Since the turrets cannot use gold in any way, this makes the Brittle Crown effectively useless for them.
 The Crowdfunder becomes self-sustaining with a Brittle Crown, as long as the player can continually hit enemies with it and avoid taking damage.


== Math ==
The formula for gold earned is: C ⋅ D ⋅ 2
C = Number of Brittle Crowns
D = Difficulty Coefficient


=== Shrine of Blood ===
The Brittle Crown has a unique interaction with the Shrine of Blood. This is no longer the case after Survivors of the Void, which changed the Brittle Crown's gold loss.

The amount of gold earned is not added to the total amount of gold when calculating gold lost.
If the player has 100 health, 100 gold, and one Brittle Crown, using the Shrine of Blood for the first time will leave them with 75 gold.
Taking 50% damage, they lose 50% of their gold, leaving them with 50 gold. The shrine always gives 50% of the health taken as gold, so they then gain 25 gold.
The Brittle Crown subtracts gold based on the player's fullCombinedHealth, which is their maximum HP plus their maximum shields. This is the same value that Shrines of Blood use, so as long as the player's fullCombinedHealth is more than two times their current gold, using a Shrine of Blood for the first time will net a profit.


== Lore ==
A wretched carnival.

They were doomed for good reason. Dunepeople of Aphelia: lost, in fanatic worship of parasitic influences. Lemurians: destined to a dead planet, picked clean. Chitin beasts. Automations of death. Why do you bring them home? They were not meant to survive. 

I have watched you for ages, from my dead rock - and every century, you disgust me with vanity. You invite vermin into your home. Wretches. Rats. Monsters. Creatures without restraint. Each and every one, planet killers. And yet, you entertain them as guests. Like children, requiring saving and protection.

She should have died for me. Her gift was wasted on you.

And when will we open discussion - dear brother - of all your thin lies? Why do you forbid your guests to leave? To pilot? Why do you fashion great walls and gates? Why do you weave constructs of destruction, if your role is protection? They are entries in your collection. You slaver. Gatekeeper. Hoarder.

Your death is fated. When you die - and you WILL die - I will be ready. I have been patient for millennia. That planet... is mine.


== Trivia ==
The logbook entry for the Brittle Crown is written from   Mithrix's perspective and references the various species on   Petrichor V and the tragedies that Providence, the main antagonist of the first Risk of Rain, rescued them from.
Intriguingly, this item and its logbook entry were added to the game before Mithrix was added as a boss.
Since the gold reward for killing monsters is tied to their amount of gold they are currently holding, if a monster gets access to this item, the gold reward can increase or decrease based on how much they hit the player or get hit respectively. This is only possible when the player has any stacks of  Eulogy Zero and it is a scenario where monsters can gain items for them to be converted to a Brittle Crown, i.e., Artifact of Evolution,   Void Fields, or Simulacrum.
The  Roll of Pennies is blacklisted for monsters, but if it were possible to give it to them, they would reward the player with more gold than naturally expected.
A   Scavenger spawning with  The Crowdfunder is another way to have a monster's gold amount altered, albeit specific to that entity.

Lunar.name: Corpsebloom
Lunar.desc: Heal +100% (+100% per stack) more. All healing is applied over time . Can heal for a maximum of 10% (-50% per stack) of your health per second .
Lunar.notes:
The Corpsebloom is a lunar item in Risk of Rain 2.
All the player's healing is increased by 100% (+100% per stack), but unlike the  Rejuvenation Rack, regeneration is not increased. Additionally, all healing is applied over time; whenever the player would heal, it is instead stored in the Corpsebloom. Every 0.2 seconds, the Corpsebloom takes from this store and heals the holder up to 2% of their maximum health (up to 10% per second). This healing cap is halved per additional stack. 
The healing increase scales linearly, while the amount of maximum health that can be healed scales hyperbolically.


== Notes ==
The holder can only store up to 100% of their maximum health as healing.
The  Rejuvenation Rack affects the Corpsebloom twice: it increases the healing when it is stored, and increases it again when the healing is actually applied. Additionally, the Rack's second healing increase is applied after the Corpsebloom caps the healing over time, meaning that the Rack also increases the maximum amount of health that can be recovered per second. For instance, with a single Corpsebloom and Rejuvenation Rack, the player receives 8 times as much healing and can recover a maximum of 20% of their health per second.
Assuming the player has at least 1 Corpsebloom, the full formula for how much healing the player receives is DirectHealing ⋅ (Corpseblooms + 1) ⋅ (RejuvenationRacks +1)^2


== Tips ==
Whether or not to pick up the Corpsebloom basically depends on how much healing the player currently has; if they cannot heal at least 10% of their max health per second, then the Corpsebloom is almost entirely beneficial. If their healing exceeds the cap, or they have large bursts of healing (e.g. from the  Foreign Fruit), then the Corpsebloom will likely be detrimental.
As a result, the Corpsebloom is generally more effective on short runs e.g. going for Mithrix without looping, and typically falls off in effectiveness on long runs, as enemies deal much more damage and thus the player must heal much more.
  REX suffers a delay on healing from all abilities while holding Corpsebloom.
While holding a  Planula and a Corpsebloom, the user heals 30 HP upon taking damage. The Planula is unlikely to exceed the Corpsebloom's healing cap.
  Shadowfade heals 18.2% of the user's max health total over 3 seconds. While holding  Strides of Heresy and one Corpsebloom,   Shadowfade heals 30% of max health while intangible and the remaining 6.4% of max health 1 second later.
Stand still while holding Bustling Fungus to store healing quickly. This can be useful during waiting periods or between waves of various battles.


== Math ==
The maximum healing per second is determined by the formula 0.1 ⋅ 1/(amount)

== Trivia ==
Initially, the Corpsebloom would give the player a 5% critical strike chance and a chance to "critically heal," doubling the amount of HP restored. The chance for this to happen would be determined by critstat/corpseblooms, and the player's chance to deal critical damage would be lowered by this amount. This was abandoned before the Early Access release because "[crit heal] wasn't as cool as it sounded". The Corpsebloom still has the internal name 'CritHeal' as a relic from this early development stage. This is not to be confused with 'HealOnCrit', which would be the  Harvester's Scythe.
Similarly to how the Rejuvenation Rack affects the Corpsebloom's healing, the effect of   Eclipse 5 reduces healing twice when calculating the heal for Corpsebloom. This makes even a single Corpsebloom a useless item to pick up on Eclipse 5 and higher.
In the RoR2 Discord poll of June 10th 2019, the Corpsebloom was voted the least favorite lunar item.

Lunar.name: Defiant Gouge
Lunar.desc: Using a Shrine summons enemies (stronger per stack) nearby. Scales over time.
Lunar.notes:
The Defiant Gouge is a lunar item in Risk of Rain 2. 
Whenever the holder activates a Shrine or Cleansing Pool, the Defiant Gouge summons enemies (more enemies per stack), much like a Shrine of Combat would. Shrines that can be activated multiple times will spawn enemies for each activation.


== Notes ==
Stacking this item will cause the summoned enemies to be more powerful and/or numerous, as though the difficulty were higher. This also means that those enemies are worth more gold and EXP when they die.
If playing with the Artifact of Sacrifice, this item can be used to acquire items more easily, as higher difficulty enemies also have higher chances to drop items. However this strategy is inherently limited by the amount of shrines one can find in any given stage.
Just like Shrines of Combat, the difficulty scaling of the enemies spawned by this item is based on the difficulty when the player enters the level, not when the shrine is activated.
Be careful when trying to get rid of this item through a Cleansing Pool while having multiple stacks or multiple lunar items, as every use that doesn't entirely remove this item will spawn enemies. This scenario can be particularly problematic if the stage happens to feature a Family Event, especially the             Void Family Event.
The Defiant Gouge will stop working after the difficulty gets too high per amount of item, similar to Shrines of Combat, because of the extreme cost of each enemy that needs to be spawned. See Directors for more.


== Lore ==
Excerpt from the folk tale “Hymn of Aphocles”:

“...The statue had been carved to the artist’s creative vision. Beautiful and powerful, its mighty marble visage shone as radiantly as the moon. However, the common folk did not share the artist’s vision. Declaring the statue imperfect, a single laborer took up his gouge and defiled the work, shaping it to his own selfish ideas of beauty.

Admiring his own work, the laborer confidently claimed that he had increased the beauty of the art tenfold. However, the artist did not hear these words. The artist felt only rage, rage at the laborer who had defiled his masterpiece, and rage at the common folk who lauded the laborer as a hero.

And just as the laborer did not recognize the beauty of the untouched statue, so too did the laborer fail to recognize the shards of marble constricting around his leg.”

Lunar.name: Egocentrism
Lunar.desc: Every 3 (-50% per stack) seconds, gain an orbiting bomb that detonates on impact for 360% damage , up to a maximum of 3 bombs (+1 per stack) . Every 60 seconds, a random item is converted into this item.
Lunar.notes:
Egocentrism is a lunar item in Risk of Rain 2, added in the Survivors of the Void expansion. 
Every 3 seconds (-50% per stack), this item generates a floating orb around the holder, up to a maximum of 3 (+1 per stack). When an orb gets close to an enemy, it rapidly homes in on it, exploding on contact for 360% damage. 
Every 60 seconds, the holder will lose one random item and gain a stack of Egocentrism. The item lost is random and can come from any rarity, including other lunar items. This timer does not change with increasing stacks of Egocentrism.


== Notes ==
Correction: The in-game description of 3s (-50% per stack) per orb is incorrect. The actual time to summon each orb is 3/stacksseconds per orb.
Since only 1 orb can be summoned per frame, this makes 60 Egocentrisms the effective limit for damage per second, at 21,600% per second. However, additional stacks beyond this still enable the player to have a larger quantity of orbs at once, giving increased burst damage at the start of an encounter.
After reaching the 15th Egocentrism, bombs will be generated further away from the Survivor, forming multiple progressively larger orbits of bombs.
The Survivor's head is replaced with a large glowing sphere.
Egocentrism will not convert any untiered items, such as the  Empty Bottle,  Delicate Watch (Broken), and even  Tonic Afflictions.
Items are chosen randomly regardless of number of stacks, rarity, or how recently they were picked up; an item with 30 stacks is just as likely to have one of them assimilated as an item with only 2 stacks.
The orbs ignore terrain completely, both when orbiting the holder and when attacking enemies.
When holding a  Brilliant Behemoth, the orbs will trigger the Behemoth's explosion on contact with terrain.


== Tips ==
Because Egocentrism will eventually consume all other items, it makes having a good equipment even more important than usual. Equipment with short cooldowns work best, such as the  Gnarled Woodsprite for consistent extra healing or  The Crowdfunder or  Royal Capacitor for long-range damage.
If the player has multiple equipment charges from  Fuel Cells, the extra charges remain even after the Fuel Cells are lost. However, after those charges are used up the player will need to find more Fuel Cells in order to store extra charges again.
The bombs' short range (and the item-consuming nature of Egocentrism) makes it difficult to use for Survivors who lack innate mobility skills, since movement-related items are always in danger of being lost.
Ironically, the bombs themselves can also provide range with enough stacks of Egocentrism. While this can still result in a loss of movement items, this can offset the range downside.
Egocentrism works best on survivable short-range Survivors such as   Mercenary,   Loader,   False Son, and   Drifter. It can also work well for   Void Fiend because of its innate ability to heal itself, even without any items.
  Engineer's turrets inherit his Egocentrisms and have a slightly higher base damage stat than him. Egocentrism makes each turret type even better at its role:   TR12 Gauss Auto-Turrets can eliminate nearby foes and defend an area even better, while the  TR58 Carbonizer Turrets charge straight towards enemies and relentlessly attack, making their offense even more dangerous.
Avoid Egocentrism when playing as the   Heretic, as losing any Heresy item will leave her with the useless   Nevermore skill in its place. This is especially dangerous when losing the  Strides of Heresy, removing Heretic's only innate way to recover her degenerating health.
This item makes getting the logbook entries for the  Pearl and  Irradiant Pearl much easier, although it is still time-consuming. By having at least 1 other item, the player can find a Cleansing Pool and complete that stage's Teleporter Event so that no enemies spawn, then repeatedly use the Cleansing Pool while they have at least 1 Egocentrism. If no Irradiant Pearls are found, they simply wait until the Egocentrism converts all the Pearls back into Egocentrism, and repeat.
Egocentrism assimilates items even while the timer is frozen in Hidden Realms. This means the player can simply idle to gain more Egocentrism for later use (either for Cleansing Pools or for fighting), without worrying about scaling difficulty.
Egocentrism provides the only way to remove non-consumable Void Items from the player's inventory, aside from using the Shrine of Order. This can be helpful in case the player accidentally picks up a void item that corrupts items important to their build, or if they simply no longer want the items. However, this is highly imprecise, and Egocentrism will very likely damage the player's build itself.
This strategy is more useful on a stage with a Cleansing Pool, as the player can convert all of the Egocentrisms into   Pearls and  Irradiant Pearls, providing increases to their stats and preventing Egocentrism from consuming any more items.


== Lore ==
...I know you can hear me.

I was willing to give you the benefit of the doubt, at first. Perhaps there was a flaw in my design.

Perhaps it was one of your games. I was even willing to forgive you.

But no, I see the truth now. You trapped me on this forsaken rock. And for what? 

Is this all for your little pets? The creatures you love so much?

Or, can I even call it love, when you would stab your only brother in the back? How could you do this to me?

I, the only one who looked out for you after her death.

I, the one who showed you how to create?

I, who HELPED to CREATE the very power you use to invite VERMIN and PESTS to our home?

I, YOUR ONLY BROTHER?

HOW COULD YOU LOVE THOSE IMPERFECT, FLAWED VERMIN BUT NOT ME? AFTER ALL I'VE DONE FOR YOU? HOW COULD YOU DO THIS TO ME?

...Say something.

Lunar.desc: Replace your Special Skill with Ruin . Dealing damage adds a stack of Ruin for 10 (+10 per stack) seconds. Activating the skill detonates all Ruin stacks at unlimited range, dealing 300% damage plus 120% damage per stack of Ruin . Recharges after 8 (+8 per stack) seconds.

The Essence of Heresy is a lunar item in Risk of Rain 2 and a part of the Heresy Set, released in the Anniversary Update. It is unlocked and starts appearing in runs after completing the Blockade Breaker Challenge.

== Notes ==

With one or more  Lysate Cells, Ruin can still be inflicted as long as at least one charge of it remains. This also means that the shot fired by activating Ruin can inflict another stack of Ruin.


== Tips ==
  Commando has exceptional synergy with this item, as he can easily add stacks of {  Ruin with his   Double Tap and the fact that Ruin out scales both   Suppressive Fire and   Frag Grenade.
 Kjaro's Band,  Runald's Band, and  Singularity Band work very well with this item, being able to deal considerable extra damage when a large number of ruin stacks are detonated at once.
Note that if ruin is applied to multiple enemies and detonated, the band activation will only apply to the first enemy hit with the projectiles fired from essence of heresy.


== Lore ==
“…and her heart, too wicked and full of hate, was left where she once stood – at the site of her betrayal.”

-The Evisceration of Kur-skan the Heretic, VI

Lunar.name: Eulogy Zero
Lunar.desc: Items have a 5% (+5% per stack) chance to become a Lunar item instead.
Lunar.notes:
Eulogy Zero is a lunar item in Risk of Rain 2, added in the Survivors of the Void expansion. 
When entering a new stage, there is a 5% (+5% per stack) chance for each item generated in the stage to be replaced with a random lunar item instead. This affects items in Chests, 3D Printers, Void Cradles, Void Potential Orbs, Rusted/Encrusted Lockboxes, the Teleporter reward, and the Cauldrons in the   Bazaar Between Time. It also affects any item dropped while the Artifact of Sacrifice is enabled, and the item dropped when using the  Trophy Hunter's Tricorn. However, it does not affect Elite equipment drops.
Eulogy Zero also affects items given to monsters. This applies to the items   Scavengers spawn with, the items given to monsters from the Artifact of Evolution, and the items monsters gain in the   Void Fields and Simulacrum.


== Notes ==
Eulogy Zero is a completely global effect. Any loot source that can be replaced will have the chance, regardless if the player who caused the item to drop has Eulogy or not.
As it is a global effect, it cannot be luck affected.
Items in chests are replaced when the stage is generated.
This means that, if picking up Eulogy Zero mid-stage from e.g. a Lunar Pod, it will not take effect until the next stage's loot is generated.
A 3D Printer that is affected by Eulogy Zero will print the displayed lunar item, but the rarity of the input item will be as though the printer was unaffected. For instance, a 3D Printer that printed white items but was affected will print 1 white item into the displayed lunar item.
Eulogy Zero can cause Scavengers to spawn with lunar items, but it does not affect their scavenging skill that gives them additional items; no matter how many Eulogy Zero the player team has, a Scavenger can never pick up a lunar item after it spawns.
The loot options generated by a Void Potential roll indepedently for replacement.


== Tips ==
Eulogy Zero cannot replace certain drops, such as  Artifact Keys and every source of temporary items.
The items dropped after opening a Scavenger's sack cannot be replaced.
Be wary that  Prison Matrix can be replaced, despite also being a quest item.
Eulogy Zero does not care about the required or banned item tags of the drop table it is replacing. As such, you could get  Shaped Glass from a Healing Chest, or get AIBlacklisted Lunar items onto enemies.
Finding a Common Printer that had its item's replaced with a Lunar item, is one of the main upsides of this item.
Eulogy Zero can make it easier to amass huge amounts of lunar items to feed into a Cleansing Pool to get many  Pearls and  Irradiant Pearls, as the holder will find lunar items in the world naturally without having to pay lunar coins (or can print non-lunar items into lunar items).
With high stacks of Eulogy Zero, it will take longer to Cleanse yourself, as some of the Pearls will be replaced into Lunars which will need to be cleansed again.
If the player is lucky enough to find an Overgrown 3D Printer afterwards, Pearls and Irradiant Pearls can then be converted into high stacks of valuable boss items.
Eulogy Zero can make it easier to find the Heresy items, as they can also replace other items.
Although the chance is small, in scenarios where enemies get items, i.e.,   Void Fields, Simulacrum, Artifact of Evolution, or   Scavengers, it is possible for enemies to gain dangerous lunar items like  Shaped Glass or  Egocentrism.
With the Artifact of Evolution and Simulacrum, where item accruement is permanent, it is possible for monsters to gain more stacks of Eulogy Zero, which can have a snowball effect.
Since Eulogy Zero is capable of replacing the items given to monsters from Artifact of Evolution, it is possible for monsters to eventually collect all four Heresy items and thus transform into   Heretic


== Lore ==
A eulogy for the victors of spiritual warfare:

This is a message from me to you.

Though in life you will stumble, stammer and fall - though you will lose your loved ones and shed more tears than your eyes can muster - in time you can find peace on the planets you call home. A small creature waiting quietly for you, a smiling face from another stream, the silence as you breathe in the scent of a new season.

Let your heart remind you why you are here; let it tell you something new and something old. A mind remembers, but a heart knows.

I love me so that I can love you too -  I've wanted to disappear before, but I've always wanted to return to see you. The grass and the leaves, the warmth of the sun and the insects at night. 

I promised myself, and I promise you: 

A victory is the reward of cumulative loss, ever present as a light at the end of the tunnel. Even in death, there is the lingering promise of new life - forever doomed to repeat the cycle.

It's getting dark. If you get lost it's alright, for now. I hope you enjoy the shooting stars. Rest in peace.

Lunar.name: Focused Convergence
Lunar.desc: Teleporters charge 30% (+30% per stack) faster , but the size of the Teleporter zone is 50% (-50% per stack) smaller.
Lunar.notes:
The Focused Convergence is a lunar item in Risk of Rain 2. It is unlocked and starts appearing in runs after completing the Never Back Down Challenge.
It makes Teleporters charge 30% (+30% per stack) faster, but decreases the charging radius by 50% (-50% per stack).
This item affects all holdout zones, including the cells on   Void Fields, the pillars on   Commencement, and the deep void signals on   Void Locus. Every time these zones are deployed, they expand at first to their normal size but then quickly shrink. The Teleporter zone is also colored blue instead of red to indicate that the Focused Convergence is in effect.
In multiplayer, this item stacks based on the total amount held by all players combined (items held by   Engineer's turrets do not count), similar to  Lepton Daisy. 


== Notes ==
The Focused Convergence is one of the few blacklisted items that   Engineer's turrets will not inherit.
The maximum effect is achieved after three Focused Convergences are obtained. Any further Focused Convergences do nothing.
Keep in mind that halving the holdout zone's radius reduces the ground area to a quarter, and the total volume of the zone to an eighth. This makes the drawback of this item much more noticeable than the player might expect.
This item only affects the Teleporter radius while the holder is alive; if a player holding Focused Convergences dies during the Teleporter Event in a multiplayer game, the Teleporter radius will expand accordingly.
The Teleporter radius will also change if the item leaves the player's inventory while it's charging, either by it being consumed by  Egocentrism or by trading it in a Cleansing Pool.
The rescue ship charge rate on Commencement is not affected by this item.
The charging zone for Pillars of Soul already become quite small when almost fully charged. They become extremely difficult to charge if the team has multiple stacks of this item.
This item cannot be obtained in the Simulacrum mode, and will appear locked if attempting to select it with the Artifact of Command.


== Tips ==
Players at   Eclipse level 2 or higher should avoid this item, since Eclipse will already reduce the Teleporter radius by half.


== Math ==
The minimum charge time is determined by the formula 90 / (1 + 0.3 ⋅ amount)
The zone size is determined by the formula 1 / (2 ⋅ amount)

Charge time is the minimum charge time with all alive players in the Teleporter zone.


== Lore ==
Gravity concentrating... falling inward, condensing, hardening.

A singularity shrinks to the point your mind inverts, reversing reality. Now return. 

Don’t the matters of the physical world seem trivial now? Your tasks in this realm are simple and hastened, all in an attempt to get reversed. How many times can you make this trip before you are claimed by its process? 

Do not let it take you. Take it instead. Here.

Lunar.name: Gesture of the Drowned
Lunar.desc: Reduce Equipment cooldown by 50% (+15% per stack) . Forces your Equipment to activate whenever it is off cooldown .
Lunar.notes:
The Gesture of the Drowned is a lunar item in Risk of Rain 2. It is unlocked and starts appearing in runs after completing the The Demons And The Crabs Challenge.
The first Gesture of the Drowned reduces the holder's equipment cooldown by half, but activates it as soon as it is ready. 
Subsequent Gestures reduce equipment cooldown by 15% each, the same amount as a  Fuel Cell.


== Math ==
The equipment cooldown is determined by the formula cooldown ⋅ 0.5 ⋅ (1 - 0.15) ^ (amount - 1)

If the player has any  Fuel Cells, add that amount to the amount of Gestures of the Drowned (as long as the player has at least one Gesture).


== Interactions ==
Only   MUL-T's active equipment will be activated by this item. The secondary equipment will not be used until it is swapped to via   Retool. This can be exploited to avoid the automatic activation for certain items, such as the  Preon Accumulator.
Despite inheriting any held equipment,   Engineer's turrets will not activate any equipment even under the effects of this item.
 Royal Capacitor will not fire unless it has a target.
If multiple charges are stored with  Fuel Cells, all charges will be rapidly used back-to-back when a target is acquired.
 Trophy Hunter's Tricorn also will not fire unless it has a valid target.
 Trophy Hunter's Tricorn (Consumed) will be rapidly used, filling the chat with text messages. This may obscure helpful information, such as when teammates ping valuable information.
 The Crowdfunder will always be active, making it difficult to purchase items, since any gold the player collects will be immediately consumed.
In later stages this is generally a non-issue, since enemies will drop much more gold than The Crowdfunder will consume.
Enabling the Artifact of Sacrifice mitigates this issue, since the player will not have to spend gold for chests.
In conjunction with enough Fuel Cells and/or additional Gestures (or  Soulbound Catalysts and enough kills before the effect expires), it is possible to keep certain item or equipment buffs active continuously.
This includes  War Horn,  Gorag's Opus,  Jade Elephant,  Milky Chrysalis,  Ocular HUD,  Radar Scanner (for interactables within range),  Super Massive Leech,  The Back-up (multiple uses stack),  Glowing Meteorite (multiple uses stack),  Helfire Tincture, and  Spinel Tonic (since the effect will never end, the player will never be afflicted with Tonic Afflictions, until they swap equipment).
 Executive Card can not be activated by Gesture of the Drowned, due to it activating automatically upon purchase.


== Lore ==
Fossils. Remnants. How cruel. 

This moon once housed life. Life that you may have held dear, had the timing been right. But our timing was wrong. We were born much too late.

Now, it is just calcium to me – and irrelevant to you. Isn’t that right?

Lunar.name: Light Flux Pauldron
Lunar.desc: Decrease skill cooldowns by 50% (+50% per stack) . Decrease attack speed by 50% (+50% per stack) .
Lunar.notes:
The Light Flux Pauldron is an lunar item in Risk of Rain 2, added in the Survivors of the Void expansion. 
After all other cooldown reduction and attack speed modifiers are applied to the holder, this item reduces both their final attack speed and final cooldowns. Cooldowns are reduced by 50% (-50% per stack), while attack speed is multiplied by 1/(stacks + 1).


== Notes ==
Correction: The in-game description of halving attack speed per stack is incorrect. Only the first stack reduces attack speed by half; subsequent stacks have a lower penalty.
Because the Light Flux Pauldron's modification applies after all other changes, it makes attack speed bonuses less effective, and offers less of a cooldown reduction in the presence of other items that provide cooldown reductions.
After applying the attack speed penalty, the game checks whether the value is less than 0.1 and sets it to that. Therefore, 9+ stacks will have the same effect on attack speed, assuming a starting value of 1.0.


== Tips ==
  Acrid can make good use of this item, as its utility skills (  Caustic Leap/  Frenzied Leap) and   Epidemic are not affected by attack speed. With a couple Light Flux Pauldrons, these skills can be rapidly used to great effect.
However,   Vicious Wounds,   Neurotoxin, and   Ravenous Bite fire much more slowly, making them much less reliable.
  Artificer is an excellent candidate for a Light Flux Pauldron because she is mostly cooldown-based. Her primary skills (  Flame Bolt/  Plasma Bolt) see great benefit from this item: just one stack will nearly allow for continuous firing of either primary skill. Both   Snapfreeze and   Ion Surge also benefit profoundly from cooldown reduction.
  Flamethrower is severely weakened because attack speed determines its number of damage ticks per second, making it the lesser choice over   Ion Surge when carrying any stacks of Light Flux Pauldron.
Both secondary skills (  Charged Nano-Bomb/  Cast Nano-Spear) charge much more slowly. The   Charged Nano-Bomb is hurt worst, since   Cast Nano-Spear still provides the utility of freezing foes and executing low-health foes without needing to be fully charged.
Arguably, despite lowering their charge rate, a Light Flux Pauldron makes these abilities easier to use because they can be held for much longer without fully charging and automatically firing. To see any regular benefit from either secondary ability, it is recommended to take no more than one Light Flux Pauldron, as the charge rate and firing animation can become intolerably slow.
  Bandit sees mixed results with this item. His primary skills (  Burst/  Blast) fire as quickly as the player can click, but are still negatively affected since they will take longer to reload with lower attack speed. Although   Smoke Bomb can be used to give a nearly permanent uptime of stealth with just one stack of this item, it does not deal much damage. His secondary skills  (  Serrated Dagger/  Serrated Shiv) and specials (  Lights Out/  Desperado) can be used more often, but the reduction in attack speed hampers their usefulness by making the firing animations of all of these abilities much slower.
The cooldown of his special skill (  Lights Out/  Desperado) is paused while he is firing it, meaning that the benefit of reducing their cooldown is offset by the drawback of delaying the start of their cooldown.(This needs testing)
  Lights Out already fully resets itself and all of his abilities (and fully reloads his primary skill) when it executes a target, making Light Flux Pauldron especially ineffective with this skill.
Similarly to Bandit,   Huntress' kit changes drastically with this item. While it does hamper both   Strafe and   Flurry's rate of fire significantly and slows down   Laser Glaive's startup animation, it does allow the player to spam their secondary, utility and special (particularly   Ballista) abilities much more often. Taking this item essentially sacrifices the effectiveness of proc coefficient-dependant items and sustained damage for extra mobility and a more bursty damage output.
This item is excellent for   Captain's   OGM-72 'DIABLO' Strike, as just a single Pauldron will reduce the cooldown from 40s to 20s. The cast time of his   Orbital Supply Beacon will increase slightly, but is not that detrimental due to its limited use.
Keep in mind that Captain's   Vulcan Shotgun will charge slower and have longer ending lag, however.
This item is difficult to use effectively on Survivors that scale heavily with attack speed.
Assuming   Commando has no attack speed increases and a single Light Flux Pauldron, his   Suppressive Fire bullet count is reduced to a measly 3 bullets.
  Engineer's   Bouncing Grenades,   Pressure Mines,   Spider Mines, and   Thermal Harpoons are all affected by attack speed.
Just one Light Flux Pauldron allows for permanent uptime of   Bubble Shield.
Although his special skills (  TR12 Gauss Auto-Turret/  TR58 Carbonizer Turret) can be placed or replaced much more frequently with the reduced cooldown, they will inherit this item and suffer from the poor attack speed. This makes them better candidates for strategies that rely on their disposability, such as using the  Fuel Array.
  Heretic's   Hungering Gaze gets a longer cooldown and more bullets by stacking  Visions of Heresy. While it may seem useful to reduce the cooldown again using the Light Flux Pauldron, the decreased attack speed makes it more practical to just use one stack of Visions of Heresy instead.
  Mercenary's signature {  Expose debuff leaves little use for this item, as hitting exposed enemies reduces skill cooldowns by 1 second. Even without this item, a skilled Mercenary player can constantly cycle through skills.
Using   Slicing Winds isn't affected by the negative attack speed, unlike   Eviscerate; making Slicing Winds more preferable if you are getting Pauldrons.
Interestingly, by using more Light Flux Pauldrons, Mercenary will stay in his   Blinding Assault and  Focused Assault state for a much longer amount of time than normal.
  Railgunner's   XQR Smart Round System,   M99, and   HH44 all fire much slower.   Supercharge not only takes longer to charge, but also disables her weapons for longer.
  Active Reload scales with attack speed, changing the size of the perfect reload zone.
  Loader isn't a bad pick with this item, as her   Grapple Fist and   Spiked Fist do not scale with attack speed, enabling incredible mobility. However, her barrier gain is significantly impacted, as   Charged Gauntlet and   Thunder Gauntlet take longer to charge and   Knuckleboom attacks slower.
  MUL-T's   Blast Canister scales with attack speed, but can be immediately fired by sprint cancelling.   Transport Mode does not scale with attack speed, so the Light Flux Pauldron allows using both in quick succession for a very high damage rate.
  REX with just one Light Flux Pauldron can achieve greater damage per second early on with   DIRECTIVE: Drill.   Tangling Growth can be maintained 100% of the time with ease thanks to the Pauldron's cooldown reduction, enabling excellent crowd control and healing.
However, the firing speed of   DIRECTIVE: Inject is reduced, which hampers its damage and self-healing over time.
With enough Light Flux Pauldrons, the cast time for their utility skills (  DIRECTIVE: Disperse/  Bramble Volley) becomes high enough that REX can walk around during the delay between activating and actually firing the skill.
  Void Fiend is terrible with the Light Flux Pauldron, as all its damaging skills are affected by lower attack speed.   Suppress and   Corrupted Suppress also take longer to cast, and have no cooldowns to begin with.


== Math ==
Skills' new cooldowns are determined by the formula cooldown ⋅ 0.5 ^ amount. Note that the minimum cooldown for most skills is 0.5 seconds.
The holder's final attack speed, however, is determined differently, with the formula attackSpeed ⋅ 1/(amount + 1).


== Lore ==
"The wind guides us all. Listen to the song of the wind, and dance according to its instruction. You will find yourself dodging every blow, countering every strike. You will find that the wind will lift you up, making you as free as a fallen autumn leaf. But heed, and do not lose yourself to the wind. Running is a viable option, though eventually you will find yourself with nowhere left to run to."

-Will of Combat, Second Excerpt


== Trivia ==
The item's lore entry seems to refer to its function. Its reduction of firing rate will make fights generally take longer, but since the majority of survivors have at least one movement-related skill with a cooldown, the cooldown reduction will often make it easier to dodge attacks, and perhaps more notably, flee from unfavorable fights that may result from the player's reduced offensive capabilities. The last line of the lore seems to caution against relying on this hit-and-run style too much, as the limited size of each stage naturally means that the whole map could eventually fill up with all the enemies a player keeps running from.

Lunar.name: Longstanding Solitude
Lunar.desc: On level up gain a free unlock for the next purchase (+1 per stack) but all gold is converted to experience. Anything that costs gold is increased by 50% (+50% per stack) .
Lunar.notes:
Longstanding Solitude is a lunar item in Risk of Rain 2, added in the Seekers of the Storm expansion.
When the holder levels up, they are granted an instance (+1 per stack, up to 3 per level) of the   Free Unlock buff, allowing them to use any interactable for free. However, any gold obtained while holding this item is converted into experience, and gold costs are increased by 50% (+50% per stack).


== Math ==
Every 25 (Scaled With Time) gold that would be gained is instead converted into 12% (+1.25% per stack, up to 20.75% at 8 stacks) of the experience required to reach the next level.
The cost per level up is decided by this formula and calculated on entering a stage:

For more information check The Math of Scaling Difficulty

The cost of a level increases over time, at the same rate as other gold costing interactable.
The cost is unaffected by Longstanding Solitudes downside.
Large amounts of Gold are often cut off and will not necessarily always equate to a level up, but gradual gold gains can use this table as a general reference.

Gaining $209, 3 times, results in 3 Levels.
Gaining $627 all at once, results in ~~2.2 levels


== Notes ==
Correction: The increased XP gain per stack is not mentioned in-game.
The cost per XP gain does not increase by 50% like the cost of interactables.
This makes stacking not have a downside in Single-Player
This is one of the few items that has arbitrary stack limitations.
Stacking past 3 does not increase the amount of   Free Unlock per level.
Stacking past 8 does not increase the amount of XP per 25$.
Gaining multiple leves at once through too much gold, will not result in multiple   Free Unlock.
This is very unlikely to happen in regular gameplay.
The holder gains the experience from converted gold in addition to the experience they would normally get with killing an enemy
This item prevents the player from charging Halcyon Shrine's, as they are unable to hold gold.
This item prevents getting more missiles with  War Bonds.
Upon reaching the level cap of 94, the player will be unable to get more free purchases.
If they run out of their   Free Unlocks, they will be unable to purchase anything until they get rid of the item.


== Tips ==
Economy items like the  Brittle Crown,  Defiant Gouge, the  Roll of Pennies, or the  Ghor's Tome greatly amplify the upside of this item.
 Brittle Crown can be especially strong since the player will always be at 0 gold and therefore be unable to lose any when getting hit.
 Defiant Gouge is especially strong when you find a Shrine of Chance, since it may take several of your   Free Unlocks to get both items.
It's best to avoid   Gilded Coast while holding Longstanding Solitude in single-player, as it will take 7   Free Unlock stacks to activate the beacons and kill   Aurelionite.
If you dont kill the boss fast enough, you would need to repeat this.
If the player is already at the level cap, you are locked in the area without escape.


== Lore ==
Day 1
The chilly coin in my pocket hums softly, drawing me off path. A pulsing blue pod is lodged in the earth here, covered in morning frost. Even through gloves, the coin burns colder than ever. I’m terrified and compelled to place the coin on the pod, it snaps open.
A dark gel oozes out, carrying a round device and tablet to my feet. The device activates and pulls the tablet with it into a hover. A construct? I know I should have shot it down, but I… feel it wants to help me get stronger.
I touch the construct. Thousands of years push their way into my skull, the mounting pressure makes me howl in a voice I don’t recognize, then nothing.
---
A pounding migraine wakes me. Midday. I feel moss under me and shield my eyes against the canopy light. I am closer to RallyPoint, but how? Disfigured beetles lay dead in a radius around me, faces distorted, limbs bent. I vomit. The construct hovers protectively nearby. How did it do this?
Day 2
Studying the tablet brings no comfort. I worry about Huang. The isolation grates on me, I’m exhausted, hungry, angry. I finally found a supply chest but the construct absorbed my coin before I could use it. This lowly thing thinks it knows best. I don’t know what came over me but I attacked the construct. It didn’t seem to mind but that only made me feel worse. I am not myself.
Day 3
The full moon’s light makes me itch. It pursues me from it’s dark sea, sluggish and unnerving. I stare into it, nearly falling into it’s gaze. For hours I run terrified in the wrong direction. I cannot face it, not how I am. Under a deep canopy I draw familiar power from the construct. Inky feathers break through the skin of my arms and hands. I black out.
Day 4
That blasted thing isn’t cheap, the construct is obsessed with coin, but I can’t argue with the results. The Lemurians barely put up a fight, obliterated, distracted by their song.
The last one drops from my talons.
They never should have been here in the first place. Where they are blind, I see the shapes of things and truly know them. I must reach…someone, somewhere. I cannot quite remember.
It is day
RatssratsRATS gther n your shadow brother. Scrub, scrub it clean. Yoo LOom
ovr the trees, for me?
I’m
ontheWAy

Lunar.name: Mercurial Rachis
Lunar.desc: Creates a Ward of Power in a random location nearby that buffs both enemies and allies within 16m (+50% per stack) , causing them to deal +50% damage .
Lunar.notes:
The Mercurial Rachis is a lunar item in Risk of Rain 2, added in Content Update 5.
The item randomly places a ward near the holder that gives the {  Power Buff status to any character within 16m (+50% per stack), increasing their damage by 50%. The character is powered up regardless of whether they are an ally or enemy. The ward lasts for roughly 27 seconds and will take another second to replace itself near the holder.  


== Notes ==
The Power Buff status only persists as long as the character stays in the ward's radius. It expires almost immediately when the character leaves the radius, or if the ward expires.
The ward has a radius indicating its area of effect, similar to the  Focus Crystal, but its actual area of effect is slightly smaller than the indicator.
While the ward's placement is somewhat random,   Engineer can utilize this item very well if his   TR12 Gauss Auto-Turrets are in the ward's radius.
Engineer's turrets will also place nearby wards.
Be aware of how large the ward's radius becomes when stacking this item. While increasing the radius gives the player more freedom to move around within, excessive stacks will make it much more likely for enemies to become powered up as well.
Unlike  Warbanner, the Radius increases by 50% of the previous stacks radius, making each stack increase the radius further than the last.


== Lore ==
“The original information super-highway: the spine. A strait-laced path from the body to the brain, it is responsible for ensuring the survival of all life. However, its limitations involve being localized to its parent body. What if - just like the development of the inter-computer wireless network - one’s nervous system could communicate with another? What if the spine traced a path not just from body to mind, but a path that intersects between other bodies and minds?”

- Notes of Job Michaels, Serial Killer and Mad Scientist

== Lore ==
Mass.

Simple, featureless, and bland. But required.

We take mass, and bring it into being.

Space-time bends around mass. We call this gravity.

The more mass, the stronger the pull of gravity.

Lesser beings may buckle under the weight. Even light may succumb to mass's pull.

Fascinating.
